Literature Review: The introduction of genetically engineered crops expressing insecticidal toxins derived from Bacillus thuringiensis (Bt) has revolutionized pest management strategies in agriculture, particularly in the United States. This literature review aims to explore the management of insect pests with Bt crops, focusing on their effectiveness, impact on pest populations, and the challenges associated with their use.Bt crops, primarily corn and cotton, have been widely adopted in the United States since their commercial introduction in the mid-1990s. These crops produce one or more Bt toxins that are lethal to specific insect pests, primarily targeting Lepidoptera and Coleoptera species. The adoption of Bt crops has led to significant reductions in conventional insecticide use, resulting in environmental benefits and increased profits for farmers (Klümper and Qaim, 2014).One of the most notable successes of Bt crops has been the regional suppression of pest populations. Carrière et al. (2003) reported that the widespread adoption of Bt cotton in Arizona led to a significant decline in pink bollworm (Pectinophora gossypiella) populations, ultimately resulting in the eradication of this pest from the state. Similar suppression effects have been observed for other target pests, such as the European corn borer (Ostrinia nubilalis) in Bt corn-growing regions (Hutchison et al., 2010).The success of Bt crops in managing insect pests has been attributed to several factors. Firstly, the high expression of Bt toxins throughout the growing season provides consistent protection against target pests. Secondly, the specificity of Bt toxins to certain insect groups minimizes non-target effects on beneficial insects and other organisms (Romeis et al., 2006). Additionally, the reduced use of broad-spectrum insecticides associated with Bt crop adoption has led to increased populations of natural enemies, further contributing to pest suppression (Lu et al., 2012).However, the widespread and prolonged use of Bt crops has also led to the evolution of resistance in some target pest species. This phenomenon has been observed in several important agricultural pests, including the fall armyworm (Spodoptera frugiperda) and the western corn rootworm (Diabrotica virgifera virgifera) (Tabashnik and Carrière, 2017). The development of resistance to Bt toxins compromises the effectiveness of these crops in managing pests and can lead to increased crop damage and yield losses.Several factors have been associated with the evolution of resistance in target pests. One key factor is the intensity of selection pressure exerted by Bt crops. Gassmann et al. (2014) found that continuous cultivation of Bt corn expressing the same toxin over multiple years accelerated the development of resistance in western corn rootworm populations. Additionally, the genetic diversity of target pest populations and the inheritance patterns of resistance traits play crucial roles in the rate of resistance evolution (Tabashnik et al., 2013).To mitigate the risk of resistance development, insect resistance management (IRM) strategies have been implemented. The primary IRM strategy for Bt crops is the refuge strategy, which involves planting non-Bt crops in proximity to Bt crops. This approach aims to maintain a population of susceptible insects that can mate with any resistant individuals that may emerge from Bt crops, thereby diluting resistance genes in the population (Carrière et al., 2016).The effectiveness of the refuge strategy depends on several factors, including the size and configuration of refuges, the dominance of resistance alleles, and the fitness costs associated with resistance. Huang et al. (2011) demonstrated that larger refuge sizes and the use of seed mixtures (refuge in a bag) could delay resistance development in target pests. However, the implementation and compliance with refuge requirements have been challenging in some regions, potentially compromising the long-term effectiveness of Bt crops (Reisig, 2017).To address the challenges associated with resistance evolution, several approaches have been proposed. One strategy is the development of Bt crops expressing multiple toxins with different modes of action, known as pyramided Bt crops. These crops can provide more durable resistance management, as pests would need to evolve resistance to multiple toxins simultaneously (Carrière et al., 2015). Another approach is the integration of Bt crops with other pest management tactics, such as cultural controls, biological control, and judicious use of conventional insecticides, as part of an integrated pest management (IPM) framework (Romeis et al., 2008).Looking to the future, the continued success of Bt crops in managing insect pests will depend on proactive resistance management and the development of novel transgenic traits. Efforts to increase the prevalence and compliance with refuge strategies, combined with the implementation of IPM practices, will be crucial in delaying resistance evolution. Additionally, ongoing research into new insecticidal proteins and alternative genetic engineering approaches, such as RNA interference, may provide new tools for pest management in transgenic crops (Joga et al., 2016).In conclusion, Bt crops have demonstrated significant potential in managing insect pests, leading to reduced insecticide use and increased agricultural productivity. However, the evolution of resistance in target pests poses a significant challenge to their long-term effectiveness. By learning from past experiences and implementing robust resistance management strategies, the viability of current and future transgenic traits can be improved, ensuring their continued role in sustainable pest management.
